conclusion: Let T be the common tension in the three equal-length ropes AC, CD, and DB.
Point C equilibrium (vertical): T sin θ = mg.
Point C equilibrium (horizontal) gives: T cos θ = T, which implies θ = 90°.
An extra horizontal pull is needed at D, so an external horizontal force F must be applied to D.
For the CD segment to stay horizontal, the vertical components of the two tensions acting at D must cancel.
The horizontal component of the tension in DB plus the applied force F must balance the horizontal component of the tension in AC.
At D: T cos θ + F = T cos θ, which leads to F = mg cot θ.
The rope length constraint for AC and CD tells us the minimum angle θ occurs when AC is stretched straight from A to C with its lower end vertically below A by a distance L.
Geometry gives sin θ = L/2L = ½, so θ = 30° and cot θ = √3.
Insert θ = 30° in F = mg cot θ to find F_min = mg √3.
The least horizontal force that must be applied at D to keep CD horizontal is F_min = √3 mg.
